intro: Galactia tenuiflora var. eriocarpa, commonly known as the hairy fruit galactia, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the legume family, Fabaceae, and is characterized by its trifoliate leaves and small, yellow flowers. The plant produces hairy, spherical pods that contain several seeds, which are dispersed by wind. It thrives in arid and semi-arid environments, often found in rocky soils and along dry streambeds. Its botanical features make it an important plant for ecological studies and traditional uses in local communities.
